titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. V:30.Mr Calhoun called this morning at my house, and I consulted him with regard to the election of a Speaker— Found him very decided against Taylor, but not decided whom to support in his stead. He did not expect Mr Lowndes would be here; and if here did not believe he would consent to be a candidate— He had been too much mortified at his failure last year— Nelson would be friendly to the Administration; but the principal objection to him was his being a Virginian. There was already an inordinate proportion of Citizens of that State in all the Departments of the Government. But as to Taylor, a large majority of the New-York Delegation, would not only vote against him; but would be much dissatisfied, if there should be any movement of the administration in his favour. And it would not only indispose them, but almost the whole of the Pennsylvania delegation too— I urged the ill example of changing the Speaker on mere grounds of party personality— That it has hitherto been unexampled since the existence of the present Constitution— The mischief of bringing into the Government of the Union, the squabbling of New-York State politics. He replied by insisting on the unnatural aspect of the administration supporting one who at least had always acted as their enemy; against those who had been its warm and steady friends— I found him so fixed that it was of no avail to press him further upon the point— He said he thought the field of Attack upon the Administration would this Session be narrowed— He is more sanguine of the increase of the revenue next year than I am; and spoke with the utmost confidence of having four Millions in the Treasury at the end of the year, after all its expenditures paid— I told him I could only hope it would so turn out.— I had visitors, at the Office; Dr Bronaugh; with Letters and Accounts from General Jackson: Mr H. Baldwin, from Pennsylvania, and Mr J. J. Morgan from New-York, members elect of Congress, and Dr. Watkins
who borrowed of me Parke and Marshall, and the French Marine Ordinance upon Insurance. He said he had a Letter from Mr Tazewell in answer to his queries; from the purport of which he inferred that Tazewell adhered to his opinions— He had no answer from judge White, though he had written him five Letters— He also told me that Baptis Irvine since he parted from Elliot had repeatedly been to him and professed the friendliness of his disposition to me; and his readiness to serve my political advancement. I told Watkins, that if I had any objects to promote by purchasing the Editor of a Newspaper, Mr Irvine was not worth buying— If management of that kind were consistent with my principles, which it was not; and if I had the talent for it, which I have not, and if I thought Irvine worth purchasing for any thing, I would pay him to write for my competitor— I did believe Irvine to be at bottom an honest man— But he was a foreigner; he had no American conceptions; and did not know the way to American hearts. His ideas were confused— His opinions Quixotic, and his principles my aversion—especially those which he has most stubbornly and odiously maintained, against the Supreme Court of the United States— Far from buying him therefore, I would not accept him as a gift. I want no supporter who holds his principles. His natural market is elsewhere. Mr Morgan spoke to me of Mr Gerard Smith an applicant for the Consulate of St. Bartholomew, or elsewhere— I told him how it had happened that Mr Smith could not be appointed to that Island; and how he would be disappointed in almost any other Consular appointment, as he had been in that of La Rochelle— Mr D. Trimble of Kentucky called also at the Office, but I did not see him. Upon a Summons from the President, I attended a Cabinet Meeting at his house at two O’Clock. It was to read the whole Message; almost all the separate parts of which had been repeatedly read, and discussed before— All present except Mr Wirt who was indisposed— After the reading various remarks were made, some by Mr Crawford and some by me, upon which slight alterations, corrections, and additions were made— The President then asked if it should be read by paragraphs; but that was deemed unnecessary. There was a general acquiescence in the whole message— After the other members of the Administration had withdrawn, the President told me that he had concluded to take no part whatsoever in the election of the Speaker— That he had given and should give no opinion on any side; and he had enjoined as strongly as he could both upon Mr Hay and Mr Gouverneur; both of whom were however quite independent of him; yet he had enjoined upon them to say nothing upon the subject to any one— I told him that under the circumstances, I should do the same—would inform Mr Dickenson of it, and also if he pleased communicate it to Mr Taylor himself; to which he assented. I then read to the President the Letter received this day from General Jackson with the enclosed papers against judge Fromentin; upon which I told him that it would deserve consideration whether some modification of that part of the Message which related to the difference between Jackson and Fromentin should not be made— As it stood it placed them both on a level; giving them both credit for upright intentions, and expressed no censure of either— I thought they did not stand upon a level; and that they ought not to be represented in the same light— He directed me to send these papers round to the other members of the Administration, and said we would meet again upon it— I asked him if they should be sent to Mr Crawford— He said at first yes; but afterwards recollecting himself said no— Mr Crawford having been ill when the papers were formerly considered, and not having seen them— I gave the papers to Mr Brent, desiring him to take them to Mr Calhoun; to point his attention to a certificate of Coll. Butler, confirming in the strongest terms a certificate before given by Dr Bronaugh, the truth of which Fromentin had most explicitly denied; and to request him after perusal of the papers to pass them over to Judge Thompson.

2. V:45. I received this morning a Note from the President, asking for the papers received yesterday from General Jackson concerning judge Fromentin; and for other papers heretofore received from both— I answered that I had according to his directions sent those received yesterday to Mr Calhoun; and that the rest were at the Office which was closed; but that I would take measures to have them all sent to him in the course of the day, or early to-morrow Morning— Mr Dickenson called upon me; and I told him of the President’s determination, to take no part whatever in the election of the Speaker— He said that the majority of the New-York Delegation had now come to their determination— They would support Mr Rodney, and if they could not succeed with him they were to take up Mr M’Lean, both members from Delaware— This was in consequence of an interview between a deputation from the majority of the Delegation, and the Secretary of the Navy, who was exceedingly inveterate against Mr Taylor, and approved of the other nominations— But he said the Southern members were not for supporting Rodney, because they considered him as a Clayite— I went with Dr Thornton and George to the Bath-Room— Met Mr Calhoun on the way. He had the papers received yesterday from General Jackson with him, and promised to leave them at the President’s, as he passed— There was no preaching at the Bath-room, Mr Little being sick. The Doctor and George returned home. I went to the Presbyterian Church at the foot of the Capitol Hill and heard Mr Post, from Acts 10.1. and 2. “There was a certain man in Cesarea called Cornelius, a centurion of the band called the Italian band— A devout man, and one that feared God with all his house, which gave much alms to the people, and prayed to God alway.” The Sermon was an analysis of the character of Cornelius, with a comment upon the superiority of practical over mere theoretical religion, and an earnest exhortation to imitate the virtues of Cornelius. I met at the Church Mr M. L. Hill of Maine, Mr. Montgomery of Kentucky, and Mr Wood of New-York— I called on J. W. Taylor at his lodgings; and found him in his chamber; apparently under some agitation. After some conversation upon the Census, and the publication of the Secret Journals of the old Congress, and some accidents which have befallen some of the members of the New-York Delegation on their way, he asked me if I knew whether Mr Rodney had arrived— I did not—but perceiving the drift of the question, I told him, that I understood Rodney was to be his competitor to-morrow. He said he had just now for the first time been so informed: and that he understood Mr Rodney was the candidate favoured at Washington. I said that if by Washington he meant the Administration of the General Government, so far as I was personally concerned in it, Mr Rodney was not my favoured Candidate— As far as I had a right to any preference it had been in his favour; because he had been the Speaker before; and because a question of re-election was different from a question of election for the first time. I added that in consequence of our conversation when he had called upon me the other day, I had expressed these Sentiments to the President; but had been assured by him, that he had taken and should take no part whatever in the election— Considering it on principle improper, for the Executive to interfere in the choice of a Speaker of the house— He said he approved of the principle, but that the members who could be influenced by such motives would be told that Mr Rodney was the person, the choice of whom would be acceptable to the administration, while others would be excited against him, Taylor, on pretence that he was a Clintonian— I said I was apprehensive, that if there should be a strong opposition to him it would arise chiefly from his own State; and its delegation. He said they would be about equally divided. He had been called falsely a Clintonian— He had for the last three years had no personal intercourse with Mr Clinton— He had been no partizan because between the two divisions of the Republican party he had seen no difference of principle. He had until his last election been supported by all the Republicans of his District, without reference to State parties; last Spring there had been a buck-tail caucus in his District, who had agreed to nominate him
together with an Assembly ticket of their own— But the Clintonians, being quicker than their adversaries, had a meeting and actually nominated him, with their Assembly ticket; upon which the other party got up an opponent to him; a Mr Van Schoonhoven, who had through the whole of the War, and until very lately had been a federalist, but had now become a republican— I said there had been an impression that in his appointment of Committees last year, he had manifested unfriendliness to the administration— I had no complaint of that sort to make, myself; but other Departments perhaps had. He declared he had never appointed a Committee or a Chairman with any such feeling— That the Committees of the second Session of every Congress were usually the same as those of the first Session— He had found them all, appointed by his Predecessor— The Chairman of the Naval Committee had indeed been changed— Mr Silsbee the former chairman could not be appointed, because he was not here at the commencement of the Session when the standing Committees were appointed— Mr Barbour, the chairman appointed in Silsbee’s stead, had indeed views in relation to the navy, which he Taylor did not approve, but he had not known them when he appointed him, and the whole Committee was so far from countenancing him, that Barbour had complained that he had given him a Committee with which he could do nothing— And in fact the Committee would not report Barbour’s project; but he was obliged to bring it forward in his own name— Of the military Committee he gave an account equally direct to disprove any hostile feeling on his part to the Administration; and he said he had been much surprized at the first intimation that such a Sentiment was entertained— As to his personal feelings towards Mr Monroe, they had been indicated in the year 1816. by the part in his favour which he had taken when the contest was between Mr Monroe and Mr Crawford— At that time certain Resolutions had been passed by the Republican members of the New-York Legislature at Albany, under the influence, and at the instigation of Mr Van Beuren; which he happened to have in his trunk, and would read to me; which he did— They were most earnest Resolutions against the election of another Virginian President, and a recommendation equally earnest of D. D. Tompkins for that high Office— Taylor said he had declined supporting these opinions, and had written in answer to the Resolutions that with all possible respect for Mr Tompkins’s character and services, it was impossible to present him as a Candidate for the Presidency with any chance of success— And he had been told that when this his answer had been made known to Mr Tompkins, he had said it was because Taylor himself did not wish for his success— He then repeated the account which he had given me last year of what he had understood as a promise from Mr Monroe of the appointment of District judge for the Northern District of New-York, and of his disappointment, when without any notice to him as had been promised, and a few days before the Session commenced, Mr Skinner had been appointed— He had been told that the Vice President, and the Secretary of the Navy had made interest against him— But General Van Ness had assured him that the President had told him there had been no opposition to Taylor through them. I said, I knew not what had been the President’s determining motive; other than as he had said to me it was because Skinner had been the District Attorney, and it was in the usual routine of promotion. Taylor said it was now past, and he thought no more about it— Taylor told me he doubted whether the Vice-President would be here this Winter— I said I thought he could not avoid coming— He said he had thought so too. But a friend of the Vice President’s had told him he thought he would not come— It would at first be said he would be here after the Holidays— Then he would be said to be in ill health, and perhaps as there was last year a certificate from Surgeons will be procured declaring that the state of his health, will not admit of his coming—this will last till about April, and then the
Session being so near its close, for a very few days it will not be worth while to come— He says there is nothing for him to do here, and any other man may preside in the Senate as well as he— From Taylor’s I went and called upon Coll. Trimble a Senator from Ohio, at Mrs Peyton’s— Met Stokes, Senator from North-Carolina, on the Avenue—just arrived— Trimble is exceedingly ill, confined to his chamber, and looking as if he would not long survive— While I was with him, his namesake, Trimble of Kentucky came in— After returning home I went to the Office, having directed the Messenger, when he came with the daily mail to order the watchman to open the door, and I searched for the papers for which the President had sent this Morning, but found only one Letter of Fromentin’s— I wrote a Note, and sent it by the Messenger to Mr D. Brent, requesting him to send the papers to the President early to-morrow Morning— I took the Letter that I had found to the President, who requested me to meet with Mr Calhoun and Mr Thompson at his house at 11 to morrow Morning. While we were at dinner, Mr William Taylor came, requesting that his commission as Consular commercial Agent might be transferred from Carthagena to Vera Cruz. I promised to speak about it to the President to-morrow. Mr Brent called in the Evening, and told me that he had found at the Office, and taken to the President a part of the papers wanted by him; the other part were locked up in the desk of Mr R. Forrest who had them to copy, and he was not at home; but they would be sent to the President early to-morrow Morning— I received two Notes from Mr Canning; one, merely asking for an interview—the other a long one upon rolled and hammered iron.

3. VI:30. The Door Keeper of the house of Representatives Joseph Claxton, died yesterday, and this morning Dougherty came to ask me to befriend him, if any of the members of the house should call upon me, recommending him for the place— Maul, a son of the former Messenger of the Department and who has been a Captain in the Army, came to the Office, to solicit influence for the same appointment. At eleven O’Clock I attended at the President’s, where I found Messrs.Calhoun and Thompson— The question upon the paragraph of the Message relating to the altercation between General Jackson, and judge Fromentin at Pensacola, was submitted. I had suggested that after the papers received on Saturday, the paragraph in the Message which gave them both equal credit for integrity of motive and intention, could not be sustained— I now observed that it put them both upon a level, which I thought could not with justice be done— Their conduct was widely different, with reference both to morals and political principle. Jackson even if he had erred, had only supported with an excess of energy the cause of Justice and Humanity— Fromentin whatever his motives were, supported by his interference the cause of fraud and perfidy. Jackson had never for a moment doubted his own right to act as he did— Fromentin’s course had been weak, inconsistent, wavering and full of prevarication— Judge Thompson said he had not been present at the former Meetings on these subjects and had not read the former papers. But he had hitherto considered their conduct as standing upon the same grounds— That Fromentin had mistaken his powers in issuing the writ of Habeas Corpus, and Jackson his in summoning Fromentin before him. But that their motives had been equally upright. I read several passages, from Fromentin’s own Letters, to shew the unsteadiness, and shifting character of his own Statements; for all of which however Mr. Thompson successively found apologies. The President read three several drafts of paragraphs to be substituted for that which had first been prepared—and a question arose whether it would not be best to say nothing of Fromentin— It was agreed that the Message in regard to Fromentin should be shaped according to the previous determination of the President whether he would or would not re-nominate him to the Senate for the permanent appointment of judge— I said that I had fully made up my mind that he ought not to be re-nominated. Mr Calhoun said if he should not be nominated the public opinion would universally be that it was because he had issued the writ of Habeas-Corpus— It would have the appearance of taking the side of General Jackson upon that point, which he thought
would injure the reputation of the Government: If he should not be nominated it would be absolutely necessary to bring the whole correspondence both of Jackson and Fromentin before the public; to which Mr Calhoun said he had the most extreme aversion— He thought therefore that the President should nominate Fromentin, and then send confidentially, the whole correspondence to the Senate; that if they saw fit, they might reject him. Calhoun seemed to have an absolute horror, at the idea of the publication of the Correspondence. I said that in the first place, I did not believe it would be possible to suppress the Correspondence. Probably not a week would pass over, before there would be a Call from the House of Representatives for documents relative to the Habeas Corpus affair, and then they must all come out. And secondly, it would not be consistent with the Spirit of our Constitution that the President should nominate to the Senate in the expectation that they will reject him, a man whom the President would not appoint, if the absolute appointment were in himself. I knew of no possible case in which it would be right for the President to nominate a man, intending him to be rejected. If the case be clear, against the man, he ought on no account to be nominated—if doubtful the President ought not to throw upon the Senate the responsibility of rejecting which he would decline to assume himself. Calhoun disputed the principle—distinguished between a new appointment and a re-appointment—thought the Spirit of the permanent tenure of judicial office, made a nomination after a temporary appointment almost compulsory— He spoke of the general spirit of Constitution as leaning towards the opinion of referring appointments to the decision of numerous bodies of men— I thought this altogether unsound political doctrine; and referred to an expression of opinion lately published in a Letter of Mr Jefferson of the great danger arising from the permanent tenure of judicial offices. Calhoun said he thought himself that judges ought in certain cases to be removable otherwise than by impeachment. But while the Constitution remains as it is, he would execute it, in its Spirit— I said the necessity of renomination was as much in the Spirit of the Constitution, as the permanent tenure of judicial office; and if it afforded even a partial remedy for the danger of indefeasible office it should rather be cherished than counteracted— Judge Thompson gave no opinion upon this question of renomination; and the President said he would keep it open; desiring more information before he should decide— No positive preference was declared, for either of the paragraphs prepared as substitutes for that which is to be altered; but from the discussion the President will form his own determination. At the suggestion of Mr Thompson he had also prepared a paragraph to close the Message with a Sentiment of religious gratitude; a Sentiment perfectly proper in itself, and which I too strongly approved to object against it— But I did not earnestly recommend it, precisely because the motive alledged for it, was its expediency or effect upon the public opinion— The President said he usually had introduced such a passage, and Mr Thompson thought the Message would in the opinions of many persons be thought exceptionable without it— There was something said about the prospects of War between Russia and Turkey in Europe, and something about the recent Revolution in Mexico— Upon both these incidents in the History of these times, I thought our information too scanty and too much derived from Newspapers to require or authorize any thing to be said in the Message concerning them— After Calhoun and Thompson had withdrawn, I told the President the substance of the Conversation, which I had yesterday with J. W. Taylor, and of my assurance to him that the President would not in any manner interfere with the election of Speaker— I told him that Taylor had declared his approbation of the principle; but said the argument would undoubtedly be used to influence votes, that another member would be more acceptable, to the administration: and I said there certainly had been some Executive influence exercised, for a deputation of New-York members, had been in concert with judge Thompson, and agreed to
vote not only against Taylor, but for Mr Rodney. The President said he had never had a single word upon the subject. He had no doubt there was something of the New-York politics in it— He said they had strictly enjoined upon Mr Hay and Mr Gouverneur to say nothing about it, though they were both independent of him— He had spoken upon the subject only with Mr Calhoun. The President also shewed me the Papers which he had mentioned to me, last Friday— They were a Letter from Talleyrand to Livingston dated 22. March 1803. most explicitly declaring that the first Consul was determined to keep and to colonize Louisiana; with a sophistical argument, a grave persiflage to shew that it would tend to promote harmony, and good-understanding with the United States—a Letter from Mr Livingston to Mr Monroe; dated 10. April 1803. addressed to him at Havre, after his arrival there from America; and he says not received till after he reached Paris— In this Letter Livingston speaks with the utmost despondency of the chances of the Negotiation, and laments that Ross’s Resolutions had not passed— Lastly minutes of the Journal of John Mercer who was with Mr Monroe as his Secretary— The minutes commence with their arrival at Havre; and continue till after their arrival at Paris which was on the 12th. of April— That Evening Mr Monroe spent with Mr Livingston; Mercer was present and kept minutes of what was said by Livingston— It was in the same desponding style, and the same regret that Ross’s Resolutions had not passed as in the Letter. Now the pretence in Armstrong’s publication is that on this very 12th. of April, the proposal for the sale of all Louisiana had already been proposed by Talleyrand to Livingston; and the dilemma upon the reputation of Livingston is, of having dissembled with his Colleague, and withheld from him the knowledge of the change in the determination of the French Government, and of his conversation of the 11th. of April with Talleyrand; or of disingenuously attempting to shew that the whole business was transacted in substance before Mr Monroe arrived— This is Armstrong’s argument, and as the cunning of Ambition deals more in equivocations concealments and evasions than in direct forgeries and falsehood’s, the conclusion I have drawn from the counter-statements on both sides is that the determination of the French Government to sell was taken before Mr Monroe’s arrival at Paris— That there was a conversation between Talleyrand, and Livingston concerning it on the 11th. of April, which Livingston reported to the Secretary of State but not to Mr Monroe— His motive for withholding it, and for continuing to represent the chances of success as desperate when he had on the same day written to the Secretary of State that the Resolution to sell, had been taken in the Council on the 9th. cannot be classed among the magnanimous impulses to action— Mr Monroe disclaims all pretension of having had any agency in producing the determination of the French Government, but he charges Livingston with unfair dealing in pursuit of the object of engrossing to himself the whole merit of the Louisiana purchase. At the Office, there came successively as visitors, Mr Poletica the Russian Minister, with Baron de Maltitz his new Secretary of Legation. Poletica has just returned to the City. He told me that he had a number of papers to communicate to me, some day when I should be at leisure—among the rest a summary of the recent negotiation between his Government and the Porte. He said the Emperor Alexander was not pleased at the interference of others, in this negotiation, and there was especially a demand of the Porte that Russia should deliver up certain fugitives to which it was impossible the Emperor should ever agree. He said I should also see among the papers a Note from Lord Castlereagh, expressing every sentiment which was contained in the Laybach circular, and against which the British Government afterwards protested— Mr Poletica likewise assured me that he had no agency in the recent publication in the Newspapers of the Emperor Alexander’s
rescript, honorary to himself; he had not received the original till his return here; the translation in the Newspapers had been published by Mr Lewis, and was not correct— It was due as delicacy from him to this Government to mention this fact— Shaler came to speak about the settlement of his accounts— I told him I had not yet been able to examine all the items of his extraordinary claims; but mentioned the objections of the Secretary of the Navy to the whole charge for acting as judge Advocate on the Court of Enquiry— After some discussion he said he should acquiesce in any allowance which the Government would think proper, presuming they would at least refund what he had paid. I told him yes, and the addition of ten dollars a day for his attendance— William Taylor came to ask what was the decision, upon his application to have the promise of exchanging the commercial agency of Carthagena, for that of Vera-Cruz— I had forgotten to mention it to the President, and went over to him again about it— He thought an appointment at Vera-Cruz now would be premature. He desired me to tell Taylor that his disposition towards him was altogether friendly; and that if the time for the appointment at Vera Cruz, should come before he goes for Carthagena, his claims for the Office will be considered. I told him so accordingly, and he took leave of me saying he was satisfied— I took to the President’s several papers of remonstrance against the re-appointment of the Marshal of Georgia, Morel, among the rest a Letter signed by the Governor, President of the Senate and Speaker of the House of Georgia, recommending Major Triplett not only as a suitable Successor, but successful competitor to . . .— I wrote a short Note to Mr Canning, informing him of the instructions to the Officers to restore the pirated Newfoundland vessel, subject to Salvage; and to Baron Stackelberg informing him of the order for restoring the Norwegian vessel Perlan— This day commenced the first Session of the 17th. Congress— There was a Quorum formed of both Houses— There were seven Ballots for a Speaker in the House of Representatives, without effecting a choice. About 60 votes for Taylor— Upwards of 100 against him— Running for Rodney, M’Lane, and others—

4. IV:15. A Man by the name of M’Dowell came this morning to solicit influence to obtain the Office of assistant door-keeper to the House of Representatives in Congress— This poor man was the third; and had the best claim of the three; for he had lost an arm in the late War— I called on Mr Josiah Meigs, Superintendent of the Land Office, and told him what I knew of G. S. Bourne’s pretensions to an appointment, in that Office— He said the vacancy, was of an able Draftsman; and such a one they wanted. Mr Canning whom I had appointed to meet at one O’Clock, came and was with me nearly three hours, conversing on a great variety of Subjects in a manner entirely desultory.— His first object was to explain to me how two American Vessels seized on the borders of the Province of New-Brunswick for smuggling, and which he, upon an application from this Government, for indulgence had recommended to the Governors of New-Brunswick, and Nova-Scotia for it, had been condemned and sold— I also read to him the papers transmitted to this Government, concerning the Caroline, a vessel tried likewise, at St. Andrews in New Brunswick, and those relating to the Fame, a vessel on trial in our own Courts— All these cases turn upon the question of the bordering line between Moose-Island, and Campo Bello. The question of transcending the proper territorial jurisdiction, to execute revenue Laws was also involved in them— Upon the identity or similitude of rolled and hammered iron, there was also much said— He insists they are the same—and I know not how to prove the contrary. I promised him to look into the subject and answer his Notes; and said if upon examination, it should be found practicable, the President would recommend it by a message, to Congress— Of the Newfoundland Pirates; Mr Canning seemed not entirely satisfied with the order to restore the vessel and Cargo
subject to the claim of Salvage for the Officers of the Customs— He said he had understood Salvage was granted only in cases of wrecks, or of recaptures at Sea. I told him the claim and its amount would both be subject to the decision of the Court— They were private and individual rights which the Government could not of right release— On the case of Carleton Island; he asked a number of questions in relation to the possession and the time when it had been taken by us. I told him the Circumstances as they were known to us— He seemed anxious to find some apology for the seizure from Kingston— I told him our complaint was of the disturbance by force of the actual state of things, while the negotiation was pending; and that the Governor of New-York had positively proposed a battle; if there should come another excursion from Kingston. But that the President had cooled his martial ardour for the present— He said it was no doubt a process against smugglers. I said if they meant to recover possession under the Treaty, they should have demanded it, as we had done in the case of the Post at the mouth of Columbia river— He said that in that case Mr Bagot had complained that we despatched the ship, without giving notice— And yet, I said we had made the formal demand of restoration more than two years before— We have therefore a much stronger cause of complaint than could be alledged by Mr Bagot— He spoke about the Slave-trade, and asked me, if I had seen a Letter from Sir George Collier recently published in the Newspapers— I had; but made no remark upon it. He asked if we had any cruizer upon the African Coast now— I said the same Lieutt. Stockton, who had captured the four French Schooners. He asked if we could not so accommodate our naval arrangements as to increase our force there— I said I could not exactly say—but our force was sufficient to banish our flag from the whole Coast— There had not been found for these two years a single Slave-trader wearing the American flag— I asked him if he recollected the hint I had given him last Spring to propose to his Government, to advise their ally the king of Denmark, to look a little to what was going on at his Island of St. Thomas— He said certainly and he had availed himself of it. I said I had seen in our newspapers, within these two days, a notice from Copenhagen, that the late Governor of St. Thomas, Bentzon, had been convicted of Slave-trade participation and sentenced to pay a heavy fine. Canning said it might very probably be the result of our former conversation— I told him we had almost got into a quarrel with France about these captures of Lieutenant Stockton— The French authorities in the West Indies, and the French Minister here were all on fire about the outrage upon the French flag, and they had sent me volumes of testimony given by the Slave-traders themselves, to prove Lieutenant Stockton was a Pirate— Not only so but the French Minister, with a lofty tone maintained that these vessels were engaged in lawful trade—greatly injured persons— Three of the four vessels were recaptured upon their prize crews— Two of them went back, not to Guadeloupe, but to French Guyana, and there trumped up this story of interruption of their lawful trade, by the Pirate Stockton. The third is brought into Boston, and the French Minister peremptorily demands that she should be delivered up to the French Consul, or to her owners—and in one of his Notes to me, says “le sort du quatriéme n’est pas encore connu”— I had told the Baron de Neuville, that I could inform him what that Sort was— She returned to the coast of Africa; took in her pre-engaged Cargo of 150 Slaves, and carried them and landed them in the face of day at Guadeloupe, with Lieutenant Inman and the prize crew from whom the vessel had been recaptured all the time on board— Canning said he hoped these facts would be made known to the world. I assured him that indeed they should— He said that De Neuville himself professed to be
very earnest for the suppression of the Slave-trade, but he was against allowing the right of search— Yet he admitted that it was the most effectual means that could be adopted for the suppression, and he, Canning, thought we should ultimately be convinced of the necessity of coming into it— I said that was impossible— There were objections of the most serious nature against the thing itself, in any shape; but unless Britain would bind herself by an Article as strong and explicit as language can make it, never again in time of War, to take a man, from an American vessel, we never for a moment could listen to a proposal for allowing a right of search in time of peace— He asked me in a half-bantering tone whether I had not intended last winter to make some such proposal to him— I told him no. We had exhausted Negotiation in endeavouring to make an arrangement with Great-Britain, on the subject of impressment— We had failed, and were not desirous of obtaining the object by indirect means— The proposal must come from them, if they were prepared for it— We merely refused to admit a right of search in time of peace. On this principle too we should give up the French vessel at Boston, at the demand of the French Minister, at least the Executive had so advised the Circuit Court— There has been a trial before that Court—but the main question was whether there was, any of our Citizens interested in the Slave-vessel; of that there was no evidence except the very slight presumption arising from the fact that she had been built in the United States— He asked me, if at the time of our former discussions I had not seen the decision of Sir William Scott in the case of the Lewis. I told him no— I had not seen it until the case of this French vessel had arisen— He was surprized at this, and said he regretted not having communicated it to me— I asked him what was the passage of Blackstone to which he had referred on the application to deliver up the Newfoundland Pirates— He said it would be found in the Index, tunder the title of Habeas Corpus. We examined both Tuckers and Christian’s Blackstone, but did not find it. He said he would send me a minute of it— We discussed the whole subject over again, and he dwelt much upon the actual delivery of the men charged with murder and forgery, by the Governor of Canada, to the Governors of New-York and Vermont— I told him that might give a claim to reciprocity from the Governors of those two States— It was at their demand, and not that of the United States, that the men were delivered up— A Similar demand might be made of those two Governors— Perhaps they might possess the authority—as bordering States they were more interested than others in the exercise of it. It was the power to deliver up, which was considered as wanting to the President— We had also much talk upon European affairs—Russia, Turkey and Greece. I told him I still thought as I had heretofore that England would not permit Russia to go to War— It was apparent that she was effectually interposing to prevent it; but how they would let off the Emperor Alexander without humiliating him seemed likely to make a difficulty; and after Strogonoff’s open breaking up at Constantinople, the Emperor could hardly recede without humiliation— Canning said he had been long at Constantinople himself, and knew how the Russian diplomatic men treated habitually the Turkish Government, which was by no means courteously— They were much accustomed to threaten them; and hard words did not carry the consequence there which they did elsewhere. He asked what part France appeared to take in this turmoil. I said it was apparent that France did not lead; and as she had heretofore been very much accustomed to lead, she might probably now not be disposed to follow the lead of others. All the Turkish Notes were said to be written by Lord Strangford— Austria was said also to take part with the Turks— But of the French Mission at Constantinople, not a word was said— At the close of this Conversation Canning told me that he had left despatches at home unopened, which came by the Packet— It appeared to
me that he came for the purpose of gathering materials for a despatch— He kept up his habitual reserve and caution in withholding all opinions of his own; and pursued as usual with great earnestness the discovery of my opinions— I took to the President’s a remonstrance against the appointment of Ashur Ware, as District judge of the United States, in the State of Maine, which I had received together with a Letter from Mr Joshua Wingate— The President told me that the House of Representatives had chosen Mr Philip P. Barbour of Virginia their Speaker— He was a new candidate, started this morning, and came in at the 12th. ballot by a vote of 88 upon 173— I asked the President what papers should be sent to Congress; and he concluded to send with the Message only those relating to the taking possession of Florida— This Evening, Mr Peter Little, a member from Maryland, and Dr Watkins called here— Mrs Adams was ill in bed the whole day.

5. VI:Mr Daniel Pope Cook, Member of the House of Representatives from Illinois; and Coll.Richard M. Johnson, a Senator from Kentucky called at my house this morning; principally with the view of recommending a Mr Peck to be District judge in Missouri— There is it seems a Mr Gray who is recommended by the whole delegation from Missouri; because he is a strong electioneering partizan of Benton’s; but a man of very indifferent character and addicted to habits of intemperance— The President’s Message was sent in to Congress at 2 O’Clock this day— I went early to the Office to see to the assortment of the papers to be communicated— But even those which the President had determined to send, were not all ready; and I was obliged to send them imperfectly in— At the Office, I was occupied upon the draft of a reply to the French Minister’s Note of 3. August last on the cases of the Apollon, Neptune and Eugene. I had not time to finish it— Mr James Strong a member of the last Congress from the State of New-York, called at my Office. He is now here upon private business of his own— Received visits or calls from Messrs.Eustis of Massachusetts— Poinsett and M’Duffie of South-Carolina, and Sergeant and Milner of Pennsylvania; but saw none of them. Dr Thornton was here this Evening. Mrs Adams, was still very unwell, and confined to her chamber.

6. V:15. Morning visitors, Messrs.Burton of North-Carolina, Alexander of Virginia, and Tatnall of Georgia. Speaking of the election of yesterday, Burton said there was some objection to it, on account of Mr. Barbour’s being a Virginian—and that it would have been perfectly easy to have carried Mr Baldwin of Pennsylvania— I said that the objection to Virginia seemed to be, that she produced too many men of merit. I paid visits to Mr Morgan, and to Mrs and Miss Dickinson, at Strother’s. Mr Dickinson was not at home— I had as visitors at my Office Messrs.Tomlinson, Barber, Sterling and Stoddard members of Congress from Connecticut, and Mr Francis Johnson, a member from Kentucky. His object was to have the printing of the Laws, restored to a Newspaper at Russelville, instead of the paper at Louisville, to which it was transferred, at the last Session of Congress— I told him I should wish to consult Coll. R. M. Johnson at whose solicitation it was transferred last year. He said that he would ask Coll. R. M. to write me a Note, or to call upon me concerning it— He said the People in his District took more interest in the matter than he had thought they would, and as the Russelville paper had been against him, if the printing should not be restored to it, they would attribute it to him. I also received an application from fourteen members of the Pennsylvania delegation in the House and the Senator W. Lowrie requesting me to appoint the Franklin Gazette to print the Laws instead of the Democratic Press in which it has been done for several years— A Similar request was made the last year, but the appointment had been made out before I received it, and Mr Roberts one of the then Senators took a strong interest in favour of Binns the Editor of the Press— I told him however that in designating the Newspapers for printing the Laws, it had
been usual, and was entirely proper to consult the Members of Congress from the several States, and always to appoint those in whose favour the delegation were agreed— If therefore at the present Session the Delegation or so large a majority of them should renew the application for I change I should feel myself obliged to make it, although I had no complaint against Binns for any deficiency in the discharge of the duty heretofore. I now took the present application to the President, and asked his advice, which was to comply with it, which I shall do, not without reluctance; for it is another instance of the ebullitions of internal State Politics overflowing upon the Government of the Union. Another affair upon which I spoke to the President was a new list furnished by Mr. Poletica, the Russian Minister, of persons attached to his Legation, in which he has included Mr Ivanoff the Russian Consul General residing at Philadelphia— He had some time since mentioned to me his wish to do this, which I had not encouraged— His object is to obtain diplomatic privileges and exemptions for the Consul General of his Nation. The President said he thought it would be dangerous to allow them, as it would form a Precedent, of which the French and British Ministers might with the more shew of reason avail themselves, inasmuch as the Consuls General of both those Nations actually reside at Washington. He desired me to see Poletica, and assuring him of our disposition to accommodate as far as was in our power the views of the Emperor, to state the necessary objections to the admission of the Consul-General to Diplomatic privileges— I left with the President, a Letter from A. H. Everett, to me, representing certain inconveniences, attached to the character of Charge d’Affaires at the Court of the Netherlands; a case for which I am afraid there is for the present no remedy; and a Letter from R. Fairchild, Marshal of the District of Connecticut, whose Commission is about to expire, and who declines a re-appointment. I wrote short despatches to R. Rush, and H. Middleton. Visits by card, from R. Wright of Maryland, with Coll. P. Reed, Mr M’Lane of Delaware, and Walter Patterson of New-York.

7. VII:30. Sunrise— Three hours too late— Morning visits from Mr Dickinson, and Coll. Dwight, a new member from Massachusetts— Mr John W. Campbell, a member from the State of Ohio, called to make enquiries concerning the Accounts of Dr Hamm, Marshal of Ohio, for taking the Census; and also concerning the charges heretofore made against Mr Hamm— I told him that the charges had been made directly to the President and not through the Department of State— The President had examined into them but had not found them substantiated so far as to authorise his removal— He said he wished to ascertain whether the charges existing against him were founded or not— If they were, he should be averse to his re-appointment, as his term of service is about to expire— If they were not, he should be entirely satisfied with the Drs. reappointment— But he had some reasons for suspecting, that one or more of his Assistants had not received the whole sum, which had been charged and allowed in the settlement of his Account for the services of that same assistant. He had reason to believe that he had in various cases, endeavoured to obtain written engagements from Assistants to take their portions of the census for less than the law allowed, and had taken to himself the balance— If this had been done extensively he might have made four or five thousand dollars by it, though he conceived the Marshal could be entitled to no more than the 300 dollars expressly allowed him by the Law— And he was the more induced to this enquiry because at the last Session of Congress, Mr Woodbridge, then a Delegate in Congress from the Michigan Territory had told him that Governor Cass had laid the foundation of a handsome Fortune, by taking the Census of 1810. and upon his enquiring how this could be upon an allowance of two hundred dollars, Woodbridge had said perhaps he had been mistaken— I told him that the accounts of Mr Hamm as they had been
settled were at the State or Treasury Department where he could have free access to them. He could there see what sum had been allowed for each and every assistant, and he could ascertain from any of the assistants themselves what they had received— If it should turn out that the Marshal had not paid over to every Assistant the whole sum that he had charged for him he must abide by the consequences; but were it so, I must further say in his behalf that he would not be alone in the opinion that some deduction from the pay of the Assistants ought to be made, for the benefit of the Marshal— Many of the Marshals, apparently without concert with one another had been of that opinion, and had advanced the clause— They had alledged much trouble and some expence in the necessary correspondence, with their assistants, and especially the heavy charge of Postage, of which I had used every exertion to relieve them, but without success. I added that they almost universally and I thought justly complained of the inadequateness of the compensation— To this Mr Campbell agreed— But he thought it could not by any means warrant the Marshal in shaving the compensation of his Assistants— He spoke also of the returns of the Assistants and said he had made a motion in the house yesterday for a Committee to bring in a Bill for apportioning anew the Representation— I told him there was yet a deficiency of the return for one district of South Carolina, which the Marshal informed me could probably not come in before the first of January; and that although the rest was all printed and in two or three days would be ready to be delivered, I had hesitated whether to send it in until the last return should be received— He thought it would be best to send them in as they now are as it would be easy to act upon an estimate of the deficient district— He said the Legislature of Ohio were now in Session, and if a Bill should speedily pass for the apportionment, they might divide the State into Districts during their present Session; but if it should be long delayed they might be obliged to meet in the Summer— I told him I would send in the returns in the course of the next week. At the Office, I had visits from Mr Fuller and Mr Nelson of Massachusetts— Nelson wished to ascertain the time, when the French took possession of the Spanish part of St. Domingo. He spoke also of the State of our commercial affairs, and asked if it was thought best to persevere in the system we have hitherto pursued, or to depart from it— I said the President’s opinion was decidedly for persevering in it. I told him the prospect there was of a change in England, and the actual state of our Negotiation with France— He appeared well disposed himself to persevere, and said that as to France, our Exports to her now were greater than they had been before our last tonnage act, and a much greater proportion of them in our own vessels— Fuller said something about the election of Speaker, which has disappointed almost every body, but has turned out entirely to the satisfaction of Virginia— M’Lane of Delaware it is said was set up by North-Carolina, at the suggestion of Mr Macon—which is strange— Mr Gouverneur brought me over from the President’s, Mr Lambert’s Report upon the Meridian, with a request that I would read it, and draft a short Report or Message to send in with it. I received three private Letters from C. Hughes at Stockholm, on the Negotiation between Russia and the Turks; with a curious extract of a Letter from Lord Strangford to him— I wrote upon the draft of a reply to the Baron de Neuville’s Letter of 3 August about the Apollon— Received visits by cards from Messrs.Borland, Hubbard, Rochester, Ruggles, Van Rensselaer and Woodcock of New-York, Barstow of Massachusetts, Hill, Cushman and Herrick of Maine, Harvey, Matson, Plumer and Whipple of New-Hampshire, and Scott of Missouri.

8. V:30. Morning visits from Mr Burton of North-Carolina, with his Colleague Mr Sanders, a new member. Also from Mr Robert Wright, of Maryland, and Mr C. A. Rodney of Delaware— Wright, with whom I sat two or three years in the Senate, has been in and out of Congress half a dozen times— He told me he did not like visiting by cards. At the Office I had visits from Mr Wood of New-York—Mr Baldwin of Pennsylvania, with his colleagues, Messrs.Farrelly and Stewart, and Mr Tomlinson of Connecticut who came to enquire if I had received the Letter from the Marshal of Connecticut, Fairchild, declining a reappointment— He said he had conversed with the Senator Mr Boardman, upon the person proper to be appointed to the Office, and had nearly determined whom to recommend— He thought the delegation would agree upon the man, which I told him would save the President much trouble— The Count de Menou came from the French Minister with a French translation of the Letter from Mr Gallatin to Baron Pasquier, on the discriminating duties; of 7. July 1820— There was a passage of it, which he said Mr De Neuville thought must be incorrectly translated, and which he wished to have compared with the original— We did compare it, and found the translation was entirely correct— He also took back the volume of Treaties, which the Baron some time since lent me; and asked for the copies of the two Decisions of the District, and Circuit Courts in the case of the Schooner Exchange. But the copies of them which I had directed to be taken were not made, and Mr Brent was obliged to ask for the loan of them a few days longer. Menou said the Baron was indisposed, or he would have called at the Office himself; but he intimated that the indisposition was imaginary; and I suppose he is somewhat shy of seeing me after the Scene of the 25th. of last Month— Menou said he continued to grow fat— I received cards of visit from Messrs.Cambreleng of New York, and Bigelow of Massachusetts— Johnson Hellen and George dined with Ogle Tayloe— I had Evening visits from Mr H. Johnson, a Senator from Louisiana, Mr Shaler, and Dr Thornton, who was hunting for a Message of President Madison relating to the Patent Office, but did not find it.

9. V:30.Mr Little continues ill, and there was no preaching at the Bath-Room. I went with George and heard Mr Lowry, preach from Luke 24–44–48. And to the end of the chapter—a discourse urging the usual topics of the incomprehensible doctrine of the atonement— After Church I returned the visits of more than forty members of Congress. First at Strother’s Hotel to Messrs.Dwight of Massachusetts and Walter Patterson of New-York— Then at Ward’s to H. Johnson the Senator from Louisiana, with whom I found the Representative from that State, Josiah Stoddard Johnston. There I got entangled in a conversation about State and federal rights and encroachments, a subject upon which the overbearing politicians of Virginia, are attempting again to kindle a flame in the Union. I found Johnston, in this respect, entirely Virginian in his politics, and discussed the question with him at much expense of time, without profit to any one, and much to the weariness of the Senator, who was cautious of committing his own opinions, but did not entirely agree with his representative. There will be much wrangling in Congress on this conflict between the federal and state authorities, with no good effect; but to the revival of faction in all its bitterness— My next visit was at Dowson’s on the Capitol Hill—where I found, in one house, Mr and Mrs Eustis, Mr Fuller, General S. Smith of Baltimore, and Mr Walker of Alabama— Here I heard from Eustis, that he had been told the Unitarian Church here was building under my auspices; and that old Mrs Calhoun, the mother of the Secretary of War’s wife, had been to the wives of all the members who have them here, intreating that any person might be elected chaplains, to the two houses, but an Unitarian— She was very desirous that Mr M’Ilvaine of Georgetown, should be chosen, but she would put up with any one but an unitarian. There
was also some talk about the prospects of War between Russia and the Turks, and I told Genl. Smith that I had received late Letters from his Son in Law Hughes, at Stockholm— At Dowson’s number two, I found Mr Crawford sitting with Mr Elliot, the Senator from Georgia, who arrived here, only the day before yesterday— My visits were to Messrs.Burton and Sanders of North-Carolina, Alexander of Virginia, and Tatnall of Georgia, all of whom I saw— I did not recognize Sanders, and asked for him when he was present— Elliot said that he had been in Boston, in the Month of August when for three weeks together, he could not see across the Street for the fog—whence I conclude that Mr Elliot as an Orator deals in Amplification— From Dowson’s I went and left cards, at Timms’s for Mr Gaillard, the President of the Senate, and Mr Dickerson of New Jersey—at Miss Heyer’s for Mr Barstow of Massachusetts, and Sergeant and Milnor of Pennsylvania; at Mrs Claxton’s, for Messrs.Harvey, Matson, Plumer and Whipple of New-Hampshire; at Queen’s Hotel for MessrsBarber, Sterling, Stoddard and Tomlinson, of Connecticut, Herrick of Maine, Wood of New-York, and Wright of Maryland; at Mrs Peyton’s, for Messrs.Hubbard, Rochester and Woodcock, of New-York, and MrM’Duffie of South-Carolina— At Brown’s Hotel, for Messrs.Cook of Illinois, Scott of Missouri, Stewart of Pennsylvania, and D. Trimble of Kentucky— There I saw Mr Philip P. Barbour, the Speaker of the House—and spoke to him of the returns of the Census, and of the Secret Journals of the Old Congress, both of which are ready to be sent in— I proposed to state the facts concerning them in a Letter to him as Speaker, which he approved— We had some conversation, upon the ratio of representation, to be fixed under this Census— He entertains the generally prevailing opinion, that the numbers of Constituents to elect one representative should be increased, so that the numbers of the House should remain much as they are at present—or very little increased— My own opinion is different, and I think the considerations in favour of retaining the present ratio, and increasing the numbers of the house preponderate over those in support of the opposite course— I shall probably be almost alone of this opinion— My next call was at Fletcher’s where I saw General Van Rensselaer of New-York, and left Cards for Messrs.Bigelow and Cushman of Massachusetts and Maine, Borland of N. York and Campbell of Ohio— Then at O. Brown’s where I saw Coll.R. M. Johnson and his brother J. T. Johnson of Kentucky— I spoke to the Coll. about the retransfer of the printing of the Laws, from Louisville to Russelville, so earnestly insisted upon by his relative Francis Johnson— The Coll. was much embarrassed what to say— He still preferred the paper at Louisville, but he was unwilling to disoblige his Cousin, and the Printer patronized by him— So he alternately recommended the one and the other, and finally left me to decide for myself— My last visit was at Mrs Blake’s, to Messrs.Woodson & Smith of Kentucky, whom I saw— I left Cards for Mr Rodney and Dr Kent— It was past five O’Clock when I got home— By the Mail I received despatches from J. Forsyth at Madrid and a Letter from Mr Strobel, the Consul at Bordeaux concerning the case of Mrs Fleury— Also a Letter from W. Tudor, with a new plan for a Town Government in Boston— The Evening was absorbed in reading these papers, so that I could not write. Mrs Adams came down to dinner, but was again very unwell afterwards.

10. V:Mrs. Adams had a very restless night, and continues quite ill— I had as morning visitors, Mr Dwight of Massachusetts with a Mr Woodbridge— Then Messrs.Rogers and S. Moore of Pennsylvania who came to enquire concerning the appointment of Printers of the Laws in Philadelphia. I told them that I should comply with the request which I had received from so large a portion of the delegation of the State, though I must acknowledge to them, it would be not entirely without reluctance— In the annual appointment of Printers of the Laws, one rule which I had always observed was to reappoint the Printers of the preceding Session, in every case where there is no
no special reason for a change. The Democratic Press, had been one of the Papers, appointed for the publication of the Laws, before, I came into the Department of State— Whatever the Merits or demerits of its Editor have been with regard to the internal politics of the State, he had given no cause of complaint, either with regard to the printing of the Laws, or to the general Government, on any other grounds— But it was obviously proper, that the wishes of the delegation from each State, should be considered and have due weight in designating these appointments, and as so large a proportion of the Pennsylvania delegation for two successive years, had united in the application for a change, I should not feel myself justified in withstanding their wish, and should appoint the Franklin Gazette, for the publication of the Laws of the present Session. Rogers said the Franklin Gazette was the paper which had the most extensive circulation throughout the State; that although the application to me was signed only by 14. members of the House of Representatives, from the State, he had given notice to all the other members, and not one of them would interfere, or have a wish in favour of Binns; the only Senator from Pennsylvania now here, had signed the paper; and the other Senator, who would be here in a few days, would assuredly have no objection to the change— I replied, that I presumed he would feel no partiality for Binns— He meant the late Governor Findlay, who will undoubtedly come as the second Pennsylvania Senator, although the election is only to be made this day— Binns and his papers have been the principal agent and instrument of the party which defeated the re-election of Findlay as Governor, and this is precisely the cause of the resentments which now urge for the appointment of another printer— A Mr Halkett, an Englishman, sent me a Card, with a Letter of introduction from Sir Robert Liston, now in Scotland, and there was a Letter from Mrs Middleton to introduce Lady Catherine Halkett to Mrs Adams— Cards of visits were received from Messrs.Nelson and John Reed of Massachusetts, Dane, of Maine, Edwards of Connecticut, M’Sherry and Buchanan of Pennsylvania. At the Office, Mr Tatnall of Georgia came to recommend a Mr Bond to be Consul, or commercial agent at Callao, or Guayaquil in Peru— Mr Thompson of Georgia came with Mr Edwards of North Carolina, who introduced him— His object was to ascertain whether Mr Triplett would receive the appointment of Marshal of Georgia— I told him I presumed he would, if the present Marshal, Morel, should not be reappointed— He said he had understood it was the intention of Mr Morel to decline a reappointment. Mr Shaler was at the Office, and spoke again about some complimentary return to be made to the Governor of St. Bartholomews, Nörderling for services to our Citizens in captivity at Algiers when he was Swedish Consul there— I received a Letter from R. M. Harrison, lately appointed Consul at St. Bartholomews, mentioning objections made by this same Mr Nörderling, to recognizing him as Consul— I received also Letters with enclosures both from General Jackson and judge Fromentin concerning the late transactions at Pensacola— I took all these papers over to the President, and again strenuously urged him not to nominate Judge Fromentin, to the Senate as the judge under the new territorial Government— The President said the nomination could not be made till the Act for reorganizing the Territorial Government should have passed, which would certainly not be, within two Months; and he again manifested a strong desire for the suppression of all these documents; the Letters both of General Jackson and of judge Fromentin. I told him I thought it would be impossible— And I said that upon the whole review of Fromentin’s conduct I thought, without imputing corrupt motives to him, that it proved him incompetent on the score even of Law knowledge, to hold the Office of judge of the United States; and I detailed the particulars of his conduct, and the weakness of his arguments in defence of it, upon which I had
drawn the conclusion— I spoke also of this claim of Mr Norderling to thanks from the U.S. and his objections to the reception of R. M. Harrison, as Consul— I supposed one of these things might be made to help the other— To be attended to as soon as possible— I received also this day from the Governor of Alabama, a supplementary return of the Census in that State, singularly made to him and not to the Department of State— To have it printed, I delay for some days the sending in of the returns— Mr and Mrs Frye spent the Evening here; whereby there was no writing for me.

11. VI:30. Visitors by card, Messrs.T. Van Swearingen, and G. B. Jackson of Virginia—and Colden of New-York. I called at Strother’s to see Mr Halkett; he was out and I left a card. At the Office there came a Wurtemburger named Zaeb, who has been four years on a visit to his brother, living in Alexandria, and now wishes to return home— I gave him a Certificate on his passport; but could not furnish him the statistical Reports on Manufactures which he wanted— Mr Dickinson, of New-York, renewed an Application in behalf of Charles A. Davis, for a consular appointment, which he had already made last year. He expects an early vacancy at the Havanna; and I recommended to him to advise Mr Davis to make a new written application and to forward as many, and as respectable recommendations as he could obtain— Dickinson spoke also to me concerning the choice of a Speaker— Calhoun and Thompson and their friends prevented the election of Taylor. But the Southern men would not vote for Rodney; and others would not vote for M’Lane— All parties were mortified by the result— Even the Virginians he says, in which I think he is mistaken. But this is certain that the new Speaker has given extensive dissatisfaction by his appointment of Committees and Dickinson says there is already more dissension in the House than there was in the whole of the last Congress. I made a draft of a Message to send with the Secret Journals of the old Congress, which I took to the President, together with the despatches received last Sunday, from J. Forsyth at Madrid— At the President’s I found Mr Calhoun and Mr Thompson— They had the annual Report of the Secretary of the Treasury under revision— A new thing. This Report, is made directly from the Secretary of the Treasury to Congress, and during this Administration has hitherto not even been communicated to the President before it was sent in— The consequence of which was that last year it presented a view of the finances quite at variance with that exhibited in the message; a circumstance seized with avidity and used with eagerness against the Administration— To guard against it this year, the President desired Mr Crawford himself to Draft the paragraphs in the Message relating to the finances which he did; and now his own Report was submitted for revision— There is no information in it—except what was already in the message— One weak point in it will probably give rise to some discussion— There is a deficiency of about one Million of dollars in the supplies of the year, which he relies will not be missed, because all the expenditures of the year, are not demanded within the year. It will not be called for at the Treasury, until sometime in the course of the year ensuing; and as the supplies of that year, are expected to be superabundant; the reliance is that that the deficiency of this year, will be made up by the excess of the next— Mr Calhoun was suggesting to the President a paragraph to be added to the report displaying this expectation in more explicit terms— There is in the Report much coquetting with the manufacturing interest; but it contains no definite views of any utility and its principal lever for raising the revenue, is to raise the duties of various articles paying 15 and 20 per Cent ad valorem to 25. Calhoun and Thompson were joking about the new Speaker and his Committees, which they thought as ill chosen and as ill-sorted, as they could have been if drawn by lot. I told them they
had truly done themselves good service by changing the Speaker.— I spoke to the President of Vice-Consuls, appointed, one by the Russian Consul General, another by one of the British Consuls, and for whom exequatur’s are desired. It was a question whether Consuls have the power of appointing Vice-Consuls, unless by special authority expressed in their Commissions. I thought the British Government had made such an objection to some of our Consuls— The President was of the same opinion—to be examined into— As I was coming out from the President’s I met Mr G. Hay, who spoke of a Mr T. Monroe, a young man who wished to go and serve in the Russian army, and wants a Letter of recommendation from me to Mr Poletica— I agreed to see Mr Hay again concerning it, to-morrow at One O’Clock— Wrote farther in the draft of a Letter to the French Minister.

12. V: I wrote this Morning two Letters to President Kirkland— Received visits by cards from Messrs.Baylies of Massachusetts, Kirkland of New-York, S. Edwards and Hemphill of Pennsylvania— I called again at Strother’s to see Mr Halkett, but did not find him— Met successively, Mr Hendricks of Indiana, with Mr Plumer of Pennsylvania, Plumer of New-Hampshire, with his Colleagues Harvey, Matson and Whipple, Nelson of Virginia, and W. L. Ball, and the Senators R. M. Johnson and Barbour. I spoke to Hendricks about a third printer of the Laws in Indiana, instead of Blackman of the Indiana Centinel who is dead— He said I should find at the Office a Letter from him, recommending a paper at Evansville— I found at the Office two Letters; one from him, and one from Mr Noble, the Senator, recommending two different papers; and each supported by an application from members of the Legislature; mostly the same signatures in both— I received also a third most earnest Letter from F. Johnson, urging again the restoration of the printing to Russelville in Kentucky, and one from Coll. R. M. Johnson again professing neutrality— I left a Card at the Russian Minister’s for his Secretary Baron Maltitz—at Captain Thompson’s for Mr Nelson of Maryland— At O’Neale’s for J. Rhea of Tennessee; and at Le Preux’s for C. C. Cambreleng of New-York. At Mechlin’s I saw Mr Poinsett of South Carolina— He has just returned from a tour to Europe for his health— At the Office, Mr G. Hay came at one O’Clock— I found that the T. Munroe, for whom he asked for a Letter to Mr Poletica, is the Son of the Post-Master of this place— Hay thinks it a tract of heroism. I a sally of romantic adventure— Hay gave me a History of Randolph Jefferson, brother of Mr T. Jefferson, and a character of J. J. Monroe, the President’s brother, neither of them flattering. Baron Stackelberg, the Swedish Charge d’Affaires came to the Office; to speak about the Norwegian claim of reciprocity for their decree admitting our vessels, on the same terms in every respect as their own. He had received new Instructions from Count Engestrom, to ask for a decision, which I told him could be made only by Congress, and had been recommended to their Consideration, as he had requested, by the President in his Message— I had just received Letters from R. M. Harrison, at St. Bartholomews, with Governor Norderling’s answer to the notification by Harrison of his appointment as Consul— It declares that he, as Governor is not authorised to recognize a Consul, without the express sanction of the king; and states various objections to the recognition, some of them personal to Harrison— Reproaches him with his squabbles with the Danish Governor at St. Thomas, with his being recalled from that office, with his misfortunes and ruin, consequent thereon; and with his having been obliged to fly, and take refuge from them under his, Norderling’s protection— I read to Stackelberg Norderling’s Letter, and told him we should be obliged to make a representation to his Government concerning it— I had never known of an example of a foreign officer’s treating
a person appointed by another Government; and accredited to him in such a manner;—it was true that Mr Harrison had been our Consul at St. Thomas— He had fallen into dissensions with the Governor, and at the demand of the Danish Minister, founded on the complaints of that Governor had been recalled— As we could not try the Merits of his dispute with the Governor, he had been recalled in compliance with the demand, without discussing the merits of the quarrel— But that Governor was Mr Bentzon; he had in all probability been in this very case in the wrong; and had very lately been by his own Government, dismissed from his Office, and heavily amerced for corrupt participation in the Slave-trade— A misunderstanding with such a man, was therefore no dishonour, and if Mr Harrison had in consequence of it been ruined, and unable to satisfy his Creditors; it was his misfortune and not his fault; not a subject of reproach; but a calamity to repair— Stackelberg said he was much astonished at Mr Norderling’s Letter, which certainly was not proper, and he could not account for it. He believed however he was so far right, that the king’s sanction was necessary for the admission of a Consul at St. Bartholomews— He had no doubt of our right by the Treaty to have a Consul there; and was assured the king would grant an exequatur immediately upon application of Mr Hughes. I received despatches from H. Middleton, and A. Gallatin—the last by the Imperial which has arrived at New-York— I continued the draft of my Note to the French Minister— Received a call for documents relative to the organization of a new Government in Florida, from MrJ Sergeant Chairman of the Committee on the Judiciary— I had a morning visit from Dr. Allison.

13. V:15. The day began with Snow, and continued with rain— Walking almost impracticable. At the Office Mr John Sergeant came to enquire for certain papers of a claimant against the Spanish Government, included in a Report made the Session before last in answer to a call from the House of Representatives— I referred him to Dr. Watkins, Secretary to the board of Commissioners, to whom all the papers that were at the Department upon Spanish claims have been handed over. I told Sergeant I had received his call as Chairman of the judiciary Committee, for information to assist in making a Government for Florida— There were a number of papers, which would be sent as soon as the copies could be finished which would be in a few days— He said there was one member of the Committee, who was for making a new Florida Government off-hand— That was Johnston of Louisiana— But he himself was in no hurry— He was going tomorrow, to return to Philadelphia and should be gone a fortnight.— He spoke of Gallatin, of Rush, of Baldwin, and of the choice of Speaker— Mr S. Sibley the Delegate from the Michigan territory, brought me a printed copy of the Laws of the Territory; and told me that G. Boyd’s second son Joshua, came with him to Schenectady where he is put to School— Mr Francis Johnson came, about his Russelville printer—for printing the Laws— I told him I had appointed him; with which he was much gratified— A Mr Jotham Sewall, a Clergyman came with a subscription paper for a Charity School in the State of Maine— He had printed recommendations, from A. K. Parris the Governor elect of the State and W. D. Williamson now one of its Representatives in Congress. I received voluminous despatches—one from A. Gallatin with a Note of 15. October to Baron Pasquier on the Commercial Negotiation. Two from R. Rush, and a Letter with a Law-argument of greater length than I was able to read, from H. Strong, the Consul at Glasgow. I continued the draft of a Letter to the French Minister upon the case of the Apollon, which I was yet not able to finish— W. A. Trimble, Senator from the State of Ohio, died this morning.

14— VII. Just before Sunrise Coll. Richard M. Johnson, Senator from Kentucky, came and spoke to me of Coll. C. S. Todd’s Accounts, and of his return to the Republic of Colombia— I told him there were various charges in the accounts, the admission of which could be authorised only by the President— I believed he had decided upon them; but the account was with the 5th. auditor Pleasonton, for adjustment. He asked if an outfit had been allowed— I said I believed not— It could not be allowed without forming a precedent for other cases which would involve great public expense— He said he had not expected it would be allowed. Todd’s object was to know whether he could take his family with him.— But he, Johnson thought he had better not— I said I thought so too; though I did not feel warranted to advise him— He said Todd’s private Affairs were very much involved, and his property had been taken, to satisfy a debt to the Bank. At Noon, I went up to the Capitol and attended in the Senate chamber at the funeral service, upon Coll. Trimble. Mr Ryland the Chaplain of the Senate was delivering a discourse, and was nearly at the close when I arrived. There was a detachment of the Marine Corps, who joined the procession for the military honours— A large proportion of both Houses of Congress attended— I did not go to the grave yard, but called at Dowson’s and left a Card for Mr Jonathan Russell— Eustis went with me, and told me that he had been asked by Mr Wood of New-York what misunderstanding there was between Russell and me? Eustis asked me if there was any thing? I said, not to my knowledge—unless Mr Russell was dissatisfied, at not having had a new appointment to a mission abroad, and imputed to me that none had been offered him. Eustis said it might be that— At the Office, Mr A. Scott who was appointed Collector for the Port of Pensacola, came to tell me, that he should depart for that place, next week, and would take Letters if desired, for Mrs Adams to her Sister Smith— As he apprehends that his Office of Collector, will not be sufficiently lucrative, he asked me if any vacancy of another Office should occur, that it might also be given to him; and said Mr Crawford had told him that two Offices might be held by one person if there was no interference in the discharge of the duties between them— He said his son had written him that it was expected Coll. Troup, would be appointed the new Governor in Florida. I received a Letter from J. O. Morse, a stranger to me, developing the views of the portion of the New-York delegation, very distinctly—or at least of the anti-Clintonian part of that Delegation— I finished the first draft of a Letter to the French Minister on the case of the Apollon— Dined at the President’s with a Company of 30. Members of both Houses of Congress, Heads of Department and others— I had some Conversation with Mr Newton, Chairman of the Committee of Commerce, who appears to be firm and sound in his opinions— Mrs T. Munroe and her Son, and Mr and Mrs Frye spent the Evening at our house— Mrs. Adams was again very sick, and confined to her chamber.

15. VI: Fahrenheit’s Thermometer at 16. At the Office, Mr James Strong, a member of the last Congress from New-York came to solicit the appointment of Governor of Florida, or in case of the non-appointment of Mr Fromentin, the Office of judge of West-Florida— He says the state of his health compels him to remove and settle permanently in a Southern Climate.
